title: gas-network-upgrade-hold-due-coronavirus
story: SGN told local MSP Colin Beattie that, following the latest Government advice to stay at home, it has had to make changes to its usual ways of working.The company is only continuing with safety-critical and emergency work.SGN stated: "We know that during the coronavirus outbreak, our communities will rely on us now more than ever to keep them safe and warm. The safety of our communities and our employees will remain our number one priority in the weeks and months ahead."It added: "We will continue to operate the   National Gas Emergency Service across the south of England and in Scotland during the coronavirus pandemic. Our engineers will continue to attend properties and make the situation safe, as always. title: shed-ruled-part-special-landscape-given-go-ahead
story: Planning officers had refused to give the go-ahead to a grain store at Cairndinnis Farm near Traprain Law, ruling it would not fit in with the Lawrsquos Special Landscape Area status.They said the new building, at nearly  metres tall and  metres by  in size, would have an unacceptable impact on views from the area.However, at a meeting of East Lothian Councilrsquos Local Review Body last month, councillors overruled the decision after declaring farm buildings an acceptable sight in the countryside.Councillor Lachlan Bruce said that the land surrounding Traprain Law was farmed land and people visiting the area would expect to see agricultural buildings.He said: ldquoIt is not aswe are putting something alien into the landscape.Mr Bruce supported an appeal against the officersrsquo decision to refuse permission for the barn.He said: ldquoTraprainLaw is one of the great sites in East Lothian. I think part of East Lothianrsquos landscape is that it is worked in land and lived in land.ldquoI do not think the public are going to be adversely affected.Fellow councillor Kate Mackie agreed, adding: ldquoEast Lothianhas a rich farming tradition and history, and that farming landscape makes East Lothian what it is.Review body convenor Councillor Norman Hampshire added his support to the appeal, pointing out that the new grain store would be one of a number of farm buildings already visible and smaller than some already there.He said: ldquoThere is a need for the building in that location to support the business that is there. I think the impact is acceptable to meet that need.The planning application was approved unanimously on appeal.

title: house-plans-former-headmasters-home
story: The Holt School for Boys opened its doors in Whittingehame House in .Now, David McMillan wants to create a new house on a neighbouring site, previously home to two semi-detached houses which were the homes of the schoolmaster and groundskeeper.The main school closed in , when the building was split into apartments. At about the same time, the semi-detached homes were turned into one house.Plans for an extension to that building were submitted in .However, according to the planning statement included in the latest proposals, plans to extend the building ran into trouble.It reads: ldquoDuring the construction phase, severe weather conditions at the time resulted in the partial collapse of the older part of the dwelling.ldquoFor safety reasons, the remainder of the old building fabric was then removed.Now, only ldquoa sizeable segment remains of the building, with Mr McMillan keen to see the land transformed.The planning statement calls for the local authority to give the proposals the green light.It reads: ldquoThe remaining segment of the original building associated with the former Holts School has been situated on the site for  years without question and is a visual blight on the surrounding area, and in turn the scenic value of the designed landscape.ldquoThe construction of the proposed dwelling will recty this, especially since it is to be identical to the extended dwelling approved in .

title: world-boxing-champion-josh-taylor-delivers-easter-eggs-east-lothian-youngsters
story: Taylor, the current IBF and WBA super lightweight champion, joined forces with the Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinner Boxes organisation who were delivering the chocolate treats to families in East Lothian.The kind-hearted pugilist, , surprised scores of children in Prestonpans, Cockenzie and Port Seton when he and his furry friend knocked on their door to hand over the free eggs.The charity took to social media to thank the undefeated boxing champ and to reveal local police officers also got in on the act with the boxer.Their message read: ldquoA huge thank you to Josh Taylor for helping us deliver Easter Eggs to the children in our community today.ldquoLots of very excited children and it was lovely to see so many smiling faces. We even got stopped by the police and thought we were in trouble but they just wanted a photo with us. Lol.ldquoSorry we could not get to every street, we did our best.One delighted customer said: ldquoA huge thank you for today. My husband died eight weeks ago and I have been struggling so much financially and mentally I contacted your wonderful project to get a chicken dinner box.ldquoI [also] asked for the Easter Bunny to visit as I knew it would be lovely for my kids ndash never did we expect Josh Taylor at the door.ldquoMy kids loved it and I have never seen them so excited or smile like this since their daddy died.ldquoThey spoke about it all day, especially my son who is a huge Josh fan ndash you have no idea the joy you have brought to this house today.Another mum said: ldquoMy two were over the moon with their eggs and a visit from the champ himself.And a delighted grandmother added: ldquoWell done guys ndash my grandson just had a visit and the look on his wee face says it all. Thank you from a grateful gran.The Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinner Boxes charity provides fresh chicken meals to people who are struggling financially in the East Lothian area.Taylor, from Prestonpans, unied the IBF and WBA super lightweight titles, as well as lting the World Boxing Super Seriesrsquo Muhammad Ali Trophy with victory over Regis Prograis in London last October.

title: coronavirus-tesco-makes-major-changes-uk-stores
story: The announcement comes as the UK enters another week of lockdown.Some of the changesmay have already been implemented in some branches, but they will be standard in all stores CEO Dave Lewis said in an email to customers.The changes include removing restrictions on products as well as more protection for checkout staff.Tesco has announced that as it stock levels are starting toto normal, it is removing the purchasing limits on the majority of its products.From today, limits will only remain on essential items such as toilet rolls, pasta and hand sanitisers.This means those customers who were planning to stock up on Easter eggs will be able to do so as restrictions will no longer apply to them.As part of its ongoing measures, Tesco is introducing one-way aisles and a one-in, one-out system across its stores.CEO Dave Lewis said: "As well as the measures we shared with you previously, wersquore introducing one-way aisles and a lsquoone-in, one-outrsquo system in stores."Wersquove maintained longer opening hours to minimise potential queuing. Do ask your local store team for the quiet times."Tesco is advising customers to ask their local stores for the quietest times to visit to avoid queuing.These times will dfer from store to store but will tend to be around an hour before closing.You may find Tesco has altered its checkouts at your local store too as the retailer has now installed protective screens at the front and back of every till at the checkout, so that all checkouts can be open instead of every other one.Tesco hopes this will prevent customers queuing longer thanthey absolutely have to during this crisis.The limit on contactless payments will start to move from pound to pound per shop.Tesco is starting to gradually update its tills.You can also use the free Tesco Pay+ app from Tesco Bank.The app has bank-level security built in and lets you pay for up to pound worth of shopping with a single contactless scan directly from your phone.During the last week Tesco has been given an initial list of , clinically vulnerable and isolated people by the Government.From this list, Tesco has identied , existing customers who will now have home delivery slots created for them.Tesco also says it is working through the list and as its teams receive more data from the Government, it will make even more slots available.

title: couple-unable-get-home-left-stranded-tenerife
story: Eileen Carmichael, , and her partner Tony Gill, , live on the townrsquos Craigleith View and initially arrived in Tenere on January .They have been staying in a rented apartment which they are still staying in and paying for.They were due to leave and travel home on March  but paid to get an earlier flight on March .The couple, who booked their holiday with EasyJet, were then told the flight was cancelled two days before it was due to leave.The flight was then deemed a rescue flight but the couple were not able to get on it as it was filled with people on package holidays so local hotels could close.They have since paid for another flight home and been offered four alternatives: March , April , April  and April  ndash all of which have been cancelled.Eileen said: ldquoItrsquos just ruined our holiday. I feel like wersquove been pushed aside.ldquoFortunately, the lady who owns the apartment is in Spain so we can stay here a bit longer. Wersquore still here, therersquos nowhere we can go.ldquoI donrsquot know what we can do. We donrsquot know how long we can stay.She added: ldquoWersquove paid twice for two separate flights.ldquoIrsquom not too fussed about that because I know we can get the money back but we just want to go home.ldquoWe arenrsquot holding much hope for the next flight on May .Eileen, who is partially sighted, added that because there were still flights coming into Tenere, the Foreign Office had told them there was nothing they could do.The pair are unable to get a direct flight home and have been offered one that takes them to Madrid, Heathrow and then Edinburgh.Eileen said: ldquoHow could we even attempt that, evenwe could manage to book it ldquoIt doesnrsquot have to be a flight to Edinburgh, even Newcastle would be fine. But we canrsquot go any further than that because of our age.ldquoBeing partially sighted, I would be unable to copeanything happened to my partner Tony.ldquoWe could be stranded here indefinitely now British airports are also closing down. I know there are people a lot worse off than us, but we just want to come home.The couple are speaking to friends and family regularly their neighbour has allowed them to use her Wi-Fi which has helped them.They have also been in touch with East Lothian MP Kenny MacAskill.A spokesperson for EasyJet said: ldquoWhere we have been required to cancel flights as a result of travel restrictions, we have been committed to getting customers home as quickly as possible and so we have worked hard to operate a programme of over  rescue flights so far, bringing over , customers home since travel restrictions have been implemented.ldquoA repatriation programme is currently being run by the UK Government and we remain in contact with them about any flights we are required to operate.ldquoWe would advise people to check they are eligible and find out how to book by visiting the lsquoReturn to the UKrsquo section of the Foreign and Commonwealth Officewebsite for thetravel advice pageof the country they are in.A spokesperson for the FCO said: ldquoOur consular teams are doing everything they can, especially for those in dficulty, to keep Brits informed on the latest developments and help themndash on commercial flights where they are still available or special charter flights as well.ldquoWersquoll continue working around the clock to bring people home.

title: poachers-net-recovered-river-tyne
story: Police discovered the net beside the river, near East Linton, yesterdayafternoon.A spokesman for Police Scotland said: ldquoIt will have been used try to illegally catch salmon and sea trout but could also catch and drown otters or birds.ldquoPoachers may be taking advantage of there presently being less public in the countryside but patrols of known hot spots for poaching will be conducted and should anyone observe suspicious activity that may be wildle crime we would urge you to contact the police on .

title: stunning-photographs-make-splash-judges
story: Models braved an indoor downpour to help create powerful images which impressed the judges sufficiently to see GWS Photography gain a Fellowship with the Master Photographers Association .Grahame Smith, who runs the business at East Links Family Park, near Dunbar, with we Allison, said the idea came about thanks to a photoshoot with a local band called Sintide.He said: ldquoThey are young lads from Edinburgh and Dunbar.ldquoI do band photography quite a lot and wanted to try something edgy. I was throwing water at them and as soon as we started doing it I thought we had something.That created the idea of doing a series of portraits as a lsquowet shootrsquo ndash all within the confines of the studio.Subjects stood in a paddling pool while Allison climbed a ladder and hosed them down with cold water.Grahame said: ldquoIt was surprisingly easy finding people to do it. I thought that would be the hard part but we have still got a waiting list.About  minutes are spent explaining to each subject how the photographs are taken and what will happen to capture the reaction.Then, Grahame has about  seconds to two minutes to get snapping.MPA qualications are very highly regarded as they must include an assessment of the photographerrsquos professional practices in the form of a lsquoWorking Profilersquo document.The portraits for the lsquowet shootrsquo were particularly unique as they were all captured in the Smithsrsquo East Lothian studio but made to look asthe subjects were in dark and moody rainstorm sets.Grahame told the Courier that the emotions and expressions photographed were genuine throughout.Judges were won over by the striking series of  images, with the majority of the models coming from East Lothian.Feedback from one judge praised the choice of using black and white for the images.The judge said: ldquoSorry but I am still overwhelmed to know how to comment. This is one of those  you love to face when displayed as prints you just stand there and say lsquowow!rsquo. Itrsquos powerful, gripping with atmosphere and expressions.Posters of the photoshoot have also been created, with the money raised going to SAMH .

title: theatre-company-declare-the-show-must-go-on-online-showing
story: Battery Theatre was due to visit ious theatres throughout the summer but has had to put its tour on hold due to coronavirus.Instead, the Dunbar-based theatre company will broadcast a performance this eveningof lsquoMary, it Began With a Lassrsquo on Facebook.Philip Kingscott, co-founder of Battery Theatre Company, was disappointed to have to postpone the tour.He said: ldquoWe were keeping an eye on how it was developing each day.ldquoHaving spoken to the venues we were booked to visit, we decided that our tour in June was just not an option.The theatre group was planning to retrace the steps of Dunbarrsquos famous son John Muir.Kirsten Maguire, fellow producer and co-founder, said: ldquoOur plan was to walk the  miles of the John Muir Way, performing a play about his le along the route.ldquoWe were booked for performances in theatres, parks and gardens, finishing our tour in our home venue, the Battery Theatre in Dunbar Harbour.ldquoWe decided to postpone the tour until  instead, but still wanted to do something for our loyal audiences.ldquoWersquove produced two plays for the Battery, celebrating Dunbarrsquos rich heritage, and it seemed a great shame to not do that again this summer.Philip told the Courier that the postponement had led to the idea of a livestream performance on social media.He said: ldquoIrsquove been enjoying the broadcasts the Met Opera in New York and, more recently, the National Theatre have been doing online.ldquoEven though Irsquom stuck inside, Irsquom still getting the opportunity to see some fantastic theatre.ldquoMore recently Irsquove been getting together with friends to all watch the broadcast at the same time and then meet up via live video chat afterwards to have a drink and chat about the show.lsquoMary, It Began With a Lassrsquo by Suzanne Lofthus was toured by Battery Theatre last summer to historic venues associated with the le of Mary Queen of Scots, also revealing the pivotal part Dunbar played in her le.It is a fast-paced journey through the le and loves of Mary. It looks at the lives of Mary and Elizabeth I, two powerful women struggling to retain control of their nations. To see the performance, go to facebook batterytheatrecompany at pm.

title: kfc-mcdonalds-among-major-national-chains-set-former-raceland-site
story: Consent for a totem pole-style sign at the former Raceland karting centre, near Gladsmuir, has been approved by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department.Drawings included within the planning application feature the logos of McDonaldrsquos, Greggs, Subway, Starbucks and KFC.The go-kart centre, to the north of the A, closed its doors in January .Just over  months later, East Lothian Councilrsquos planning committee gave planning permission to transform the site into a roadside service station.During a presentation, it was claimed that more than  jobs could be created.Each of the five businesses were approached for a comment on the latest plans.A spokeswoman for KFC confirmed they were looking into setting up a restaurant in East Lothian, with hopes to open next year.She said: ldquoOur restaurants may be closed for now, but wersquore not stopping making plans for !ldquoWersquoll be winging our way to East Lothian early next year ndash watch this space.Meanwhile, a spokeswoman for Greggs said: ldquoAt the moment, this is not something Greggs will be able to comment on so we are politely declining this opportunity.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said the names of the businesses featured in the image could change.She added: ldquoWe are concerned with assessing permission for the advertising board, not its content.ldquoSo absolute confirmation of what businesses are going on site will need to come from the applicant.Currently, East Lothian is home to one McDonaldrsquos restaurant in Dunbar, with further plans being weighed up for another fast food restaurant in the car park at Musselburghrsquos Tesco store.Greggs has branches in Musselburgh, Tranent, Haddington, Prestonpans and North Berwick, while Subway can be found in Musselburgh and Haddington.A Starbucks has been mooted for the outskirts of Haddington, while the former Raceland site would welcome East Lothianrsquos first KFC.

title: hopes-mekala-home-christmas-recovery-continues
story: Mekala Osborne was travelling through South East Asia last autumn when she became seriously ill.Diagnosed with bronchial pneumonia and given just a five per cent chance of survival, her family were told to ldquoexpect the worst.However, the -year-old is continuing her incredible recovery in Edinburghrsquos Astley Ainslie Hospital and her step-dad, Jimmy McAulay, is hopeful she could be back home in Wallyford in time for the festive season.He said: ldquoIt is absolutely amazing.ldquoWhen you look at the first photograph back in September of her lying in hospital in Da Nang [Vietnam] and she had a five per cent chance of survival and then look at her now.ldquoShe is still not the same Mekala we know but she is getting there.ldquoShe has got a big smile on her face and we FaceTime every night to keep in touch.ldquoShe is amazing and she can now move a couple of fingers on each hand.After being taken to hospital in Vietnam, she was flown to Singapore for further medical treatment.Then, in November, she was flown home from Asia and spent time in the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh before moving to the Astley Ainslie Hospital last month.Her step-dad said the progress was impressive and noted she was now sitting up and had an assisted shower for the first time since initially falling ill.Jimmy told the Courier it felt ldquolike yesterday when they first heard that Mekala had taken unwell in Vietnam.Initially, she had phoned her family complaining of a sore throat.Doctors gave her antibiotics and painkillers but she ended up in hospital and had to be put into an induced coma.Jimmy was pleased to say Mekala was ldquogetting back to normal and thanked members of the public for their continued support.He said: ldquoThe response we get is absolutely phenomenal.ldquoEvery time, people wish her the best and that comes from Canada, the USA and Australia ndash it is unbelievable.ldquoIt is absolutely astonishing and we will see a wee comment online and click on it and it is someone from over in Canada or Australia. You think lsquoMy Godrsquo but that is social media for you.Former Preston Lodge High School pupil Mekala is continuing to get physiotherapy at the hospital in the Capital.Family and friends have been unable to see her during the coronavirus lockdown, which Jimmy said was hard for all involved.He added: ldquoShe is missing home really bad. I am hoping she is home for Christmas ndash fingers crossed.And, when she does come home, Mekala will have a new friend alongside her in the house, a German Shepherd puppy called Rio.Jimmy said: ldquoShe totally loves him and gets all the photographs of him.ldquoWe get him on when we are FaceTiming her and she is really chuffed with it all.

title: cruise-companys-fleet-spending-lockdown-together-firth-forth
story: Fred. Olsen Cruise Lines has paused its cruise operations and all sailings until May  ndash its Balmoral, Boudicca, Braemar and Black Watch ships have been in the Firth of Forth for more than two weeks now.The ships are based near Rosyth but can be seen from across the East Lothian coastline, including from places such as North Berwick and Cockenzie and Port Seton.Peter Deer, managing director of Fred. Olsen Cruise Lines, said: ldquoLast month, we at Fred. Olsen Cruise Lines made the dficult decision to pause our cruise operations voluntarily for a period of time, as many other cruise operators have done.ldquoIn the meantime, we have been working with Forth Ports and have secured safe, temporary anchorages for our ships in the Firth of Forth.ldquoEach ship will retain a small team on board to continue essential operations, and locals might see the ships move within the river from time to time to carry out their duties.ldquoWe look forward to brighter times ahead and to welcoming our valued guests back on board when the time is right for us all.However, eight crew members on board the Black Watch ship have tested positive for Covid- and six others are still waiting on test results.It is understood their treatment is being managed on board the ship and there are no plans for anyone to disembark.Each crew member is occupying their own cabin, each with a balcony.There are no social gatherings on board and crew only leave their cabins to perform essential duties such as bridge watch, engine watch and food preparation.Those who have tested positive or are feeling unwell are not undertaking any duties.The Braemar ship made headlines last month when it became stranded in the Caribbean with five people on board who had tested positive for the virus.

title: tims-tales-appreciate-nature-doorstep
story: SPRING has sprung and normally I would be spending most of my free time exploring East Lothian for story ideas or walking in the woods, or combing the coast and finding ldquosecret magical places with my family.Irsquove always loved spring. The burst of le and colour with the longevenings resurrects my mood, enlivens my nature-loving soul. It makes our days feel longer while also giving us the extra energy to enjoy them.How can we not be uplted by the sight of a tree in full blossom bathed in sparkling sunshine, or a carpet of wild flowers especially after months of winter when the land sleeps, and the sun seems to have forgotten us But these are not normal times of course and the ability to roam in nature and soak in its wonder has been temporarily restricted. In fact for many of us our normal le routine has been totally suspended.While we are in lockdown, nature is enjoying the opposite itrsquos flourishing with new le and beauty. And while itrsquos frustrating that we cannot venture out in ways we might be used to, I have been able to listen more closely to the stories that nature is telling on my doorstep.Over the last few years I have deliberately lsquore-wildedrsquo my small garden which I am so lucky to have. By that I mean I have allowed nature to do its thing, and nature has accepted the invitation. Elder, rowan, silver birch and cherry trees now enclose my wee patch of the world. Wild flowers such as dandelion and forget-me-nots have sprung up and last year I had foxglove, so Irsquom waiting to see what this summer will bring.A strange effect of all this has been the enlarging of my garden. Not literally, but in the power of its presence. Irsquove noticed how a space full of nature feels bigger than one thatrsquos bare, lsquoneatrsquo and manicured.I like to call it the forest horizon effect. Compare standing in the middle of a wide open treeless park with standing in the middle of a wood surrounded by trees and humming le. The area of the wood may be much smaller than the park, but its impact on our senses is much greater. We are embraced by nature, not just physically but also,we feel the connection, emotionally and spiritually. The space actually feels larger than it is because there is more in it.I am missing this embrace so much right now because of the inability to visit my favourite woods. But the lockdown has compelled me to spend more time in the natural world on my back doorstep.And within the embrace of my gardenrsquos re-wilded forest horizon, although only a space of around  metres by , I have discovered the truth contained in the wonderful book by Scott Sampson How to Raise a Wild Child.In his book, Scott states: ldquoWhen I began on this book, I had a certain sense of self-satisfaction, convinced that a letime of outdoor play, hiking and campinghellip had forged within me a deep bond with naturehellip Instead, I found that, like most of us, I was oblivious to most of the natural goings-on around me.He explains how he then spent time with his daughter absorbing the sounds and sights of nature on his doorstep, which fostered their lsquointernal wildnessrsquo more than any trip to a remote wilderness. They listened to birdsong and sat quietly as small creatures played out their lersquos dramas under the shadow of their house. ldquoWildness just outside the front door, Scott writes, ldquowas helping us deepen our bond with nature. Such interactions, I have come to realise, are essential to nature connection.Reading this has given new meaning to the confinement imposed by the lockdown. Never before have I had such time to simply sit and absorb the tiny goings on in the garden, embraced by my own mini forest horizon.A garden is a privilege, of course, and I understand many donrsquot have one. But wildness can also be found on our walk to the shops, on verges and public green spaces, with trees, bushes and wild flowers that grow in our urban spaces. The trick is to pause and absorb the wonder of it, listen and look for the wee miracles that we usually donrsquot notice and walk by. Itrsquos easier now, even on a normally busy street, with so much reduced traffic noise and absence of bustle.On my exercise walk yesterday I did just this and was overwhelmed by the beauty of renewed le. It occurred to me that this precious one-walk-a-day has intensied the connection it gives me to local nature.And never have I enjoyed the privilege of having a re-wilded garden so much. On Easter Monday I sat in it with my five-year-old son. His attention span can be short but I explained what we were doing and he stayed with me for  minutes. The first thing I noticed was the absence of normal background noise, which heightened the volume of naturersquos spring melody.Our garden attracts many birds which sit on the branches and sing their hearts out. I know they donrsquot sing for us, but my young son thought they were doing just that. In just  minutes we heard or saw coal tits, wrens, wood pigeons, willow warblers, magpies and a robin. Irsquod never have previously known what some of these birds were, but now we are in a mindset to get to know who is inhabiting our lsquodoorstep wildnessrsquo.We also watched a peacock butterfly explore our garden as it fluttered and paused in equal measure. The sound of bumblebees arrived and we saw them hover over the dandelions. Then a small honey bee made an entrance, likewise visiting the dandelions. As we sat quietly, the sound of honking above us raised our heads and we saw two V formations of geese heading north.When my boy got restless, I suggested we crawl like explorers in the grass to see what we could find. We spotted an incredible sight: young garden spiders emerging from their egg sack which was half hidden under a curve in a plant pot. My sonrsquos fascination at this was matched by my own! It was early for this to happen, and we found many other egg sacks where still unhatched.Within these  minutes there was so much le and wonder so many stories to discover. Where did the small birds come from, where were the geese going, why do bees suddenly appear and what did they do during the winter  Why are dandelions so popular with the bees, what is so special about them  Why do the birds sing dferently, are they speaking to each otherso, what are they saying How did the peacock butterfly get its name and where did it hibernate, was it in our garden shed  What was it looking for  Were the hatching spiders emerging early because their mother deliberately chose a warm corner in the garden to lay her eggs  Why do some spiders live in the garden, while others like hiding under your bed  Do you know how to spot the dference, and do they spin their webs dferently These were just some of the stories my son and I wondered about after our  minutes together in our garden wilderness. But such drama happens all around us. Little patches of mini wilderness are everywhere,we hone our senses to notice and appreciate them.I realise now the lockdown, although stressful, has created the conditions for the discovery of so many new things, with so many new nature stories to learn tales of survival and adventure, of lersquos drama happening on our doorstep and in our street.And the biggest story of all is that everything around us is ultimately related. We are part of naturersquos story because we are part of nature. We share a common ancestor with every creature and plant yes, even with the trees.So while I, like us all, yearn for the end of the lockdown for many reasons, I am also going to try to make the best of it by being more aware of naturersquos wonders that are literally outside my window, while I stay at home to help keep others safe.

title: uk-economy-braces-biggest-recession-300-years-due-lockdown---likely-recover
story: While adjusting to le in isolation has been dficult, businesses have been hit particularly hard by the restrictions, with the budget watchdog now warning the country could suffer its biggest recession in  yearslockdown continues into the summer.The Office for Budget Responsibility has said the economy could shrink by  per cent this spring, with unemployment levels reaching . million over the coming months - its highest level since the s.The struggling economy has sparked comparisons to the financial crash in , and the Great Depression of the s, but experts are now predicting the outcome will be much worse.Experts now believe the UK is headed for its biggest economic slump since , when the country was hit by a deep freeze that spread across Europe.Temperatures plummeted on January , bringing with it the worst winter in  years and freezing over several countries, including France, England and Russia.The lsquoGreat Frostrsquo, as it came to be known, lasted for three months and sparked food shortages, thousands of deaths in France, and a huge deficit to the economy.The coronavirus pandemic could see the economy shrink by a record  per cent by June, the Office for Budget Responsibilityhas warned.A drop this big would mark the largest decline ldquoin living memory, Robert Chote, chairman of the OBR has said.However, Chancellor Rishi Sunak stressed that this forecast is just one possible scenario, and it merely suggests the scale of what the country is currently facing will have ldquoserious implications for our economy.He said: ldquoWe came into this crisis with a fundamentally sound economy, powered by the hard work and ingenuity of the British people and British businesses.ldquoOur planned economic response is protecting millions of jobs, businesses, self-employed people, charities and households.ldquoOur plan is the right plan.Mr Sunak assured that the government would not stand by and will act to support the economy, adding that the OBR expects the economic impact of the pandemic to be temporary.Despite being forecast for a signicant decline, the UK is expected toto its pre-coronavirus economic growth by the end of this year, with the OBR stating this amount will depend on how long the lockdown lasts.The OBR predicts that any drop in growth will be reversed in the three months to September, as the economy starts to recover.However, it warned that the pandemic may have a more lasting impact on unemployment, which is estimated to rise to . million by the end of June.Unemployment levels are currently . million, marking a rise from . per cent to  per cent.Unemployment rates are expected to remain high until , before dropping back to four per cent, according to the OBRrsquos forecast.

title: 11-year-olds-thank-letter-delights-ambulance-staff
story: Sarah Brady, , a primary seven pupil at Wallyford Primary School, was taking part in the first lsquoClap for our Carersrsquo event on March  with mum Samantha.She noticed the ambulance sitting at the end of her street so quickly drafted a letter and ran over with a rose and gave it to them.The letter read: ldquoThanks for everything yoursquore doing for the world, love Sarah Brady.Samantha said: ldquoThe clap was amazing.ldquoA few days later the ambulance had to come back to my house for my partner.ldquoThe ambulance lady said that two men were in Wallyford recently and someone gave them a letter and that they were really overwhelmed. I said to her: lsquoThat was my daughter.rsquoldquoShe made two grown men really emotional and they were apparently telling everyone about it.ldquoIrsquom just glad she could make them smile, she does everything she can to help everybody.Samantha was then told that the men still had the letter and the rose was in a vase in their office.And Sarah has since dyed some of her hair red in tribute to the NHS.

title: north-berwick-hotel-keeping-doors-open-key-workers
story: The Nether Abbey Hotel shut its doors to the public last month for the first time since , and all its staff are observing the stay-at-home advice.The hotel is, however, continuing to provide a place to stay for those who are still working and need to undertake essential travel.Its owners, Jela and Stirling Stewart, wanted to follow all Government instructions, including First Minister Nicola Sturgeonrsquos request that hotels remain open to support those providing vital services.The couple said: ldquoAt first we were not sure who would need accommodation or who would be travelling.ldquoHowever, it soon became apparent that we needed to continue to provide this service, and companies are really grateful that we are open to them, albeit in a very altered state with extremely limited facilities.ldquoSo far we have had engineers who are carrying out vital works at Torness and a representative of a company who needed to travel from the south of England to repair vital agricultural equipment.ldquoWe have also had NHS staff who are working nights and then going home to try and sleep in a household with young children and just want somewhere quiet to sleep during the day ndash we are offering this service to all key NHS workers and emergency services free of charge.ldquoGuests are restricted to their rooms to protect us and the remaining couple of volunteers, and all public areas are closed off.ldquoLuckily there are still a few takeaways open, which means they can get an evening meal and we provide a breakfast for them to take to work.ldquoWe are observing a strict rota of rooms that are used and these are not entered for  hours after someone has departed to ensure we minimise all risk. Deep cleaning then takes place.ldquoIt has been quite tough going but as more small hotels shut their doors completely, we feel we canrsquot turn our backs on those services and members of the public that need us now.For further information call Stirling or Jela Stewart on   or email bookings@netherabbey

title: belhaven-brewery-gives-huge-boost-folk-band
story: Belhaven Brewery gives huge boost to folk bandKinnaris Quintet won the Belhaven Bursary for Innovation in Scottish music.Belhaven Brewery gives huge boost to folk bandKinnaris Quintet won the Belhaven Bursary for Innovation in Scottish music.Kinnaris Quintet were named the winners of the Belhaven Bursary at MG ALBA Scots Trad Music Awards in Aberdeen.Belhaven Brewery, which toasted its th anniversary last year, has been supporting Scottish artists through the Belhaven Bursary for Innovation in Scottish Music since its inception in .The career-changing sum of pound, is the biggest financial award for music and was awarded to Elephant Sessions in  and Talisk in .Kinnaris Quintet are the first all-female band to scoop the prize.Gordon Muir, marketing controller at Belhaven Brewery, was ldquothrilled to award the bursary to the Glasgow-based group.He said: ldquoTheir musical range, innovative arrangements and vibrant stage presence stood out among an amazingly talented shortlist.ldquoSince coming together in , Kinnaris Quintet have brought a fresh energy to the trad scene and we look forward to the bursary helping them spring to the next level.ldquoIt has been inspiring once again to see the depth and breadth of innovation in the Scottish folk music scene, with an array of brilliant artists weaving in inspiration from all sorts of genres and cultures to create exciting new sounds.ldquoBelhaven Brewery are proud of our links with this wonderful scene with which we see so much in common ndash inspired by our traditions and roots, which we use to spur our imagination to create new beers and new music that bring people together for great times.Winning the judges over with their uplting and powerful music, the quintet will also be brewing their own beer with Belhaven and performing at the Belhaven Brewery VIP Party in New York during Tartan Week.Propelling onto the scene with their debut album Free One in , fiddlers Aileen Gobbi, Laura Wilkie and Fiona MacAskill, alongside mandolin player Laura-Beth Salter and Jenn Butterworth on guitar make up the band, who mix traditional Scottish and Irish influences with contemporary compositions.

title: carla-flying-flag-east-lothian-major-pageant
story: Carla Beaton is one of  young women taking part in Miss International UK, with the winner going on to represent the United Kingdom at Miss International in Tokyo later this year.The -year-old, who is Miss Edinburgh International, got confirmation that she would take part in the competition in June earlier this month.She said: ldquoA few people have said pageants are so old fashioned and demeaning but I donrsquot think so, maybe in the past, but really they exist to empower women.ldquoEspecially coming from my background, I want to inspire people that nothing is impossible, there are no limitations to where you can go and they are a really powerful tool.ldquoWhen I first got the email, I almost cried.ldquoI was so happy but the following night I could not sleep thinking about what will I wear  WhatI fall ldquoIrsquom excited but nervous too.The former Edinburgh University student would not only wear a crown and sashshe won but would also receive items from the competitionrsquos ious sponsors.Carla graduated with a degree in politics in  and now works at the Scottish Parliament for one of the countryrsquos South of Scotland MSPs.Carla said: ldquoMy main drive behind politics and wanting to get involved is wanting to make a dference.ldquoBeing adopted, I wanted to do something for those kids who are not as lucky as myself.ldquoI thought pageants were a really good way of doing it and raising the profile of a charity. I am really keen to work with Action for Children Scotland.The Gford resident is also keen to promote the work of SAMHand how exercise and physical wellbeing can improve a personrsquos mental health.The former Yester Primary School pupil was a competitive cheerleader while at university, which sparked a love of fitness.She said: ldquoObviously, for me, health is a really big thing. I want to promote exercise and healthy living ndash not only to improve physical health but mental health.Now, ahead of the event, which takes place at the Park Hall Hotel, near Preston, Carla is looking to strike up a partnership with local businesses. The competition is split into three rounds: eveningwear, swimwear and judgersquos interview.She said: ldquoI am interested in reaching out to bridal and local couture and just small businesses that could really benefit from the publicity.ldquoAlso, hair salons, nail technicians ndash those kind of people, it is a beauty pageant first and foremost.ldquoAnybody that is involved in that world, Irsquom looking to reach out to.Get in touch with Carla at c.l.beaton@gmail

title: couples-diamond-anniversary-party-hold-thanks-virus
story: Robert and Kay Mackie, of North Crescent, celebrated  years of marriage on April .They had originally planned a meal with  close friends and family at the Prestoungrange Gothenburg on April , but the dinner had to be postponed.Robert was born in Edinburgh on November , , and has lived in Prestonpans all his le, attending local primary and high schools.He worked in a garage and then as a miner, working in dferent pits until his retirement in .He is a keen golfer and a member of the Royal Musselburgh Golf Club.Kay was born in Canada on November , , but moved with her family to Carmichael, Lanark, when she was three or four years old.The pair met dancing at the Cavendish club in Edinburgh in May , and were engaged at Christmas the same year.They married a year later at Glencorse Church, near Penicuik.Kay worked in an office until she and Robert started their own family Sheila was born in  and Diana in .The family lived in Cockenzie for seven years before moving to Prestonpans. Robert and Kay have now lived in the same house for  years.Sheila explained why her parents had decided to marry on April .She said: ldquoMy mumrsquos only brother, Michael Robertson, was emigrating back to Canada and she wanted him at the wedding.ldquoThat was the only date they could get before he emigrated he moved back the week after and still lives there now. It was nothing to do with April Foolrsquos Day!The pair have three grandchildren, one great grandson and two step-great granddaughters. Sheilarsquos eldest son, Calum, was born in  and she said the new grandparents were soon taking on babysitting duties.Sheila said: ldquoTheyrsquore really family orientated and helped a lot with bringing the kids up. They would go to their house after school.With celebration plans now on hold, the family instead spent part of the morning waving to the happy couple from afar.Sheila said: ldquoWe went round in the morning and waved in the window. It was nice to see them theyrsquore celebrating so many years married.When asked their secret to a long and happy marriage, Sheila added: ldquoThey said to listen to each other and to not go to bed on an argument.

title: pupils-parents-praised-dedication-home-schooling
story: Schools throughout East Lothian shut their doors on March  ndash two weeks before they were scheduled to close for the Easter break ndash due to the coronavirus.The earlier closure has created challenges to ensure pupils are still receiving education but Sue Cook, headteacher at Knox Academy in Haddington, took time out to praise pupils, parents and carers.Ms Cook said: ldquoThank you to you all as parents carers for facilitating learning at home and trying to maintain a routine with your young personas this can be quite a challenge, especially as many of you will be continuing working from home too.ldquoIf your young person can manage to do two three hours of learning a day that is really great as we know that access to laptops etc. may be required by other family members as well.ldquoToo much screen time is also not great for them and time off computers and devices can also be productive.ldquoEncouraging young people to exercise, outsidepossible, to get some fresh air into their lungs should be encouraged as this is great for both mental and physical health.ldquoReading a book is also excellent for developing literacy and extending their vocabulary which in turn helps support learning across all subjects.ldquoThis time of school closure and Covid- should also afford you time to connect as a family and engage in other activities such as baking or cooking dinner, playing board games or them doing some household chores.Ms Cook offered ldquoa huge well done to the many youngsters who had ldquoengaged really well with remote home-schooling.She highlighted pupils could continue to engage with their teachers through Google Classroom, and added there were a range of other websites which offered information, such as Scholar UK and BBC Bitesize.

title: authors-get-pupils-track-new-adventure-stories
story: More than  children packed Belhaven Hill School before the lockdown to listen to Maya Leonard and her co-author Sam Sedgman talk about their brand new book, Adventures on Trains: The Highland Falcon Thief.Youngsters from Law Primary School in North Berwick and Dunbar Primary School joined the hosts and were enthralled by the authorsrsquo stories.The Highland Falcon Thief is the first book in a major new childrenrsquos mystery series entitled Adventures on Trains.Maya told the children that she had two sons who loved trains, but before she started writing the book with Sam, she had had no interest in them.Sam, on the other hand, told the gathering that as a child he would run down to the end of the garden just to see a train passing, and that he had actually driven a steam train.They elaborated on the benefit of writing an adventure story set on a moving train.They called the setting a lsquoclosed systemrsquo in literary terms: ldquoNo one can get off and no one can escape! explained Sam.When the authors first decided to write a series of four books, they agreed that some signicant research into steam trains would be important.Maya began to find the subject matter more and more interesting, she told the children, especially when they visited the National Railway Museum and saw the royal carriages used by Queen Victoria.Near the end of the talk, a section of the book was read out to the enthralled audience.Each of the four books in the series is based on a real train or route.

title: corn-exchange-revamp-hold-due-coronavirus
story: Work on the townrsquos Corn Exchange began in February last year, with East Lothian Council initially expecting to see the building re-open at the start of November .However, that date was pushed back when specialist contractors carried out extensive survey work and found additional work was required.Now work on the Court Street building has stopped due to Government guidance surrounding coronavirus.A spokeswoman for the local authority said: ldquoWork has stopped on the Corn Exchange. They continued as long as they could but Government guidelines mean all non-essential construction work has been suspended.ldquoThis will obviously have an impact on completion dates but, until we know when these restrictions will be lted, it is impossible to evaluate what that will be.ldquoWe expect the completion timescales from restrictions being lted to be longer than the lockdown period itself, as the site will need to get back up and running again.ldquoThis would include organising and co-ordinating sub-contractors who may have businesses that have been affected by the closure.In , East Lothian Council set aside more than pound, to cover the cost of revamping the building.Work on the building, which has held events ranging from art exhibitions to a performance by The Proclaimers, is to include new roof lights, roof repairs and repairing the timber flooring in the main hall.

title: fundraising-event-help-horses-called-off-due-coronavirus
story: The centre lost seven of its horses to grass sickness in , a disease that affects and is major cause of death in the animal ndash about  per cent of cases of grass sickness in horses are fatal.Grass sickness damages parts of a horsersquos nervous system and can cause paralysis, which is one of its main symptoms.The cause of the disease is unknown and there is currently no cure.Seona Cunningham, , a helper who has been visiting the stables since she was  years old, said: ldquoWhen I found out that my horse had grass sickness I fell to the ground.ldquoWe are all close to our horses, the kids especially, they were heartbroken when the horses died.ldquoMost of the kids had lost their favourite ponies.ldquoThey think grass sickness is something to do with pests in the grass or something in the mud but they really donrsquot know.Harelawrsquos riders have put on their onesies in May for the past six years and completed a ride around the Gosford Estate, raising money for the Equine Grass Sickness Fund, based in Penicuik.The charity raises funds to research the disease and improve treatment for the whole of the UK.Seona said: ldquoThe ride started off as a wee thing and itrsquos just grown arms and legs and got bigger every year.ldquoEveryone felt that because we lost those seven horses that we should do something.Over the past six years, those at Harelaw have raised pound, for the Equine Grass Sickness Fund.Seona said: ldquoIrsquom surprised we have raised that much.However, due to the coronavirus pandemic and ongoing restrictions, Harelawrsquos planned charity ride has now been cancelled.Seona said: ldquoItrsquos been a horrible turn of events, itrsquos went from fundraising for this amazing cause to now struggling to stay afloat.ldquoThe stables has been forced to close its doors understandably but now no income means no money coming in to feed the horses.She added: ldquoWe have started a JustGiving page for the stables, purely to raise funds so we can feed our horses, itrsquos such a horrible time for all.Anyone wanting to donate can do so at justgiving crowdfunding brenda-findlay

title: art-therapy-charity-teapot-trust-makes-services-available-online
story: The Teapot Trust has made its one-to-one art therapy available via video conferencing and put in place new protocols for online safety.This will ensure that children and young people living with chronic conditions, who are experiencing heightened anxiety in these unprecedented times, wonrsquot miss out on the regular therapy they rely on.Delivering art therapy online is something the charity was already exploring as a means of reaching those in rural locations but coronavirus accelerated those plans.Teapot trustee Dr Simon Hackett recently secured funding from the Carnegie Trust to research this topic.The charityrsquos art therapists can now be involved in the research to assess the impact of this new work.In addition to online therapy, and to keep children creatively occupied at home, a suite of resources developed by Teapot Trust will soon be available on its website. Fun activities, task sheets and video clips will be available.Teapot Trust CEO Sarah Randell said: ldquoIrsquom so proud of our team of art therapists and core staff who together have quickly transformed the way we deliver art therapy. Theyrsquove created a secure online world so that children donrsquot miss out on an important part of their lives which helps them cope better with the impact of their conditions.ldquoGiven that many fundraising events have been cancelled or postponed, a donation to Teapot Trust, no matter how small, will help us to ensure that we can continue supporting children and young people remotely at this challenging time.ldquoWersquod also love to hear from anyone keen to fundraise in new and creative wayshellip online tea party, anyone The Teapot Trust, based at Stuart House, Eskmills Park, provides a programme of art therapy in hospitals to support children and young people with chronic conditions and their families.The charity, which celebrates its th anniversary this year, was founded by Laura and John Young, of Gullane, after their daughter Verity died from cancer in November .Verity also suffered lupus and had spent most of her le in hospital. She had taken comfort in art as a way to escape.To donate or find out more, visit teapot-trust.org

title: volunteers-helping-throughout-musselburgh
story: The emergency efforts are being co-ordinated by Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council and Musselburgh Area Partnership as they do what they can to support the communities of Musselburgh, Wallyford, Whitecraig and Old Craighall, which have a combined population of about ,.They are working from the Resilient Musselburgh Hub, which is based at Pinkie St Peterrsquos Primary School.Iain Clark, area partnership chairman, said: ldquoThe support to Resilient Musselburgh from community volunteers has been fantastic and has allowed us to deliver much-needed support to those who need it most.ldquoOur volunteers have been deployed every day and are providing a much-needed and crucial service.ldquoWe now have  amazing volunteers registered and they have been deployed on a daily basis to assist in delivering lunches to the vulnerable, emergency food supplies, prescriptions and leafleting targeted areas of the community.ldquoVolunteers are contacted as available and attend at the hub, where their delivery is brought out to them."ldquoThey have also been attending ious chemists to uplt and deliver prescriptions.ldquoThey must be on the Resilient Musselburgh register to be deployed as this provides public liability insurance cover.ldquoWe have funded the emergency food provision through the purchase of supplies which have been made into emergency packs which include food and items for personal hygiene. We also maintain a stock of sanitary products and hearing aid batteries.ldquoDuring the weekend period, when the hub is not open, a quantity of emergency food provision is relocated to allow provision over the weekendurgently required.The team has delivered  five-day lunch packs to families in the community, and volunteers in Whitecraig have also distributed  meals, supplied by local restaurant the Mercat Grill.Mr Clark said: ldquoMusselburgh Area Partnership has been allocated pound, by East Lothian Council from the Scottish Governmentrsquos Food Fund.ldquoWe are working with Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council to focus these new funds to provide the most positive impact we can to those who need our support. We are also supporting Wallyford and Whitecraig Community Councils as we look towards a co-ordinated effort during these very dficult times for many.Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council has allocated pound, and a further pound has been donated by Wallyford Community Council to help fund the initiative.Mr Clark said: ldquoWe are currently managing all the calls that come via our dedicated number, co-ordinating the registration and deployment of all volunteers and maintaining an action database of all requirements to ensure a log of what needs done and when it has been completed.ldquoIn addition, we are dealing with all the elements of the referral forms from the East Lothian Council Contact Centre that require action from Resilient Musselburgh. Given the current social distancing requirements, the co-ordination is being undertaken remotely via shared online access.ldquoWe are still looking to build on our pool of volunteers to ensure sustainability, soyou know of anyone who would be interested in supporting us then they can register using the following link and scrolling down to Resilient Musselburgh Covid-: eastlothian.gov.uk musselburghapAlister Hadden, chair of Wallyford Community Council, and Shona Bennett, chair of Whitecraig Community Council, highlighted the teamrsquos ldquoamazing volunteers, saying they had nothing but ldquoadmiration and praise for them.The hub has priority access to Tesco Musselburgh to buy emergency food supplies when necessary.Tesco has donated pound in vouchers and provides a free weekly supply of fresh fruit to support lunch provision for vulnerable people.Resilient Musselburgh has been nominated by the Pinkie Farm Shop for a pound grant from its charity MADL .For help contact the Community Resilience phone line:  .

title: let-us-race-pleads-racecourse-boss
story: Musselburgh Racecourse general manager Bill Farnsworth says the only way to save the sport is to allow racing to resume.Racing across the United kingdom has been suspended since March .However during a video conference meeting of Musselburgh Racing Associated Committee, which oversees the East Lothian course, Mr Fanrsworth warned that only theof racing itself will save it for the future.He said: "The only thing that will save us is getting us racing again."Racing needs to get racing again, it will be behind closed doors but racing is unique because that is viable because of the digital s which allow us to show races and betting to operate online."Mr Farnsworth told the committee it was nearly impossible to predict the impact of the racing closures on Musselburgh.He said staff at the course have been furloughed, but they were lobbying to find a way to hold races behind closed doors as early as June or July.And he said the Racecourse Associationhas been urging the Horse Betting Levy Board to release some of an estimated poundmillion it has in its reserves to pay courses abandonment payments to help them weather the storm.He said: "We believe the Levy Board should be paying racecourses an abadonment payment. In recent years that payment responsibility was taken up by Media Rights but the Levy Board is sitting on poundmillion so they should use some of that."Musselburgh ward councillor Stuart Currie, who sits on the committee, described the claims the Levy Board, which is a non departmental Government body, had so much money in reserves as "outrageous".He said: "The British Horseracing Authority needs to step up and step out and get some of that cash out to the industry."It is outrageouspeople are potentially going to the wall."

title: pink-door-gets-green-light
story: The stunned home owner was ordered to make a retrospective planning application by East Lothian Council planners after they were alerted to the change in the conservation area.A single complainer lodged an objection to the colour of the door, telling planners it was ldquotoo bright and not in keeping with other doors on the street.However the applicant highlighted other doors in her street which are painted red, yellow and blue in her defence of the decision.And planning officers received letters supporting her decision to paint the door which is not visible from the street.Granting permission for the pink door to remain, the planning officer said: ldquoThe door, whilst visible from a neighbouring first floor flat, is only visible in short duration glimpsed views from the public road.ldquoIn those short duration glimpsed views, the door, whilst painted pink, is not so discernibly from public places that it detracts from or be seen tobe harmful to the character and appearance of the conservation area.ldquoNor is it seen to be at odds with the colour of other doors of neighbouring residential properties.Applying for planning permission for the paintwork, which is described as coral, the home owner said: ldquoI had no idea that I needed planning permission for this and assumed it would be okay as there are many other strong coloured front doors in our local streets.ldquoOur door was chipped and neglected and I was aimingto make it appear smarter ndash it very much ties in with my design aesthetic and these colourful front doors are becoming increasingly popular in both conservation areas and outwith.She pointed out that the front door of her house, on Dirleton Avenue, was not visible from the street because of high hedges and its corner location.She added: ldquoWe invested considerable money in upgrading the front door and the gilded lettering and have received many compliments.

title: royal-mail-launches-thumbs-postie-campaign---get-involved
story: Heres what you need to know.Contact free deliveryA spokesman for the Royal Mail said: "The initiative is a simple way for the public to say thanks and stay connected with their local postmen and women, while respecting the Governmentrsquos social distancing rules."Giving a thumbs up is also a handy reminder not to reach out to try and take parcels direct from postmen and women to ensure contact free delivery."Royal Mailrsquos postmen and postwomen are at the heart of the communities in which they work. With the country observing Government advice to stay home, for many people their local postman or woman may be one of the few friendly faces they see each day."The delivery oflettersand parcels is an important way to keep connected for those who may be unable to leave their home."Thank you messagesThe move comes as postmen and women across the UK have been inundated with thank you messages and pictures from children and customers.As well as giving their posties a friendly thumbs up when they see them, Royal Mail is asking customers to share selfies with their thumbs up using the hashtag #ThumbsUpForYourPostie.Ricky McAulay, national service delivery director atRoyal Mail Group, said: ldquoWe know how much people like to say hi or have a chat with their postie on the doorstep.ldquoDuring this time, we need to find new ways of staying connected whilst also protecting our communities.ldquoWe hope that giving a thumbs up is a handy way of reminding people to keep a safe distance when we are out and about delivering the post.ldquoI would also like to thank our people for doing such a great job at this challenging time.The postal giant is also encouraging children to put lsquothumbs uprsquo pictures in their front window.Where can I get a template Templates are available to download from royalmail.

title: residents-wrongly-accused-self-isolating-second-homes
story: Reports of people being confronted by strangers about their right to be in their homes have surfacedin coastal towns with a numberrevealing they have received anonymous notes through their doors.One elderly woman of Goose Green Road, Gullane, was told in an unsigned letter she would be reported to the police after the accusers wrongly claimed her house was her second home.Her local councillor Jeremy Findlay is now passing the letter, which he described as ldquointimidation, to the police.He said: ldquoWhile people coming to isolate in second homes is not desirable, other people should be careful to check facts before issuing unwarranted letters or making personal comments to other residents.ldquoIf anyone feels that someone  is not obeying the social isolation rules as laid down by the government then they should contact the police or localauthority and not take matters into their own hands.Tom Drysdale, chairman of Gullane Area Community Council, said: ldquoIt is very unfortunate that people in the community are resorting to that sort of communication, itrsquos very upsetting for people.ldquoOn the other hand people have an obligation to stick to the rules. Any people taking up residence in their second home should be discouraged. Threatening people is not part of it.A woman living on Melbourne Road, North Berwick, who did not want to be identied, revealed she received an anonymous letter saying, ldquoI donrsquot think this is your principal residence ! You are aware of the instruction lsquostay at homersquo.She said: ldquoMy first reaction was to laugh at the absurdity of it.ldquoThen I was angry. Who did this person think they were  WhatI had been ill or vulnerable either physically or mentally ldquoThis person clearly had no idea who lived here. They could have done so much damage.ldquoThis sort of behaviour is not what North Berwick needs.The woman added her next door neighbour had also received a similar letter.A week later the neighbour was asked by a stranger who came onto their drivethey lived there permanently andthe house was their permanent residence.Judy Lockhart, chairwoman of North Berwick Community Council, said: ldquoNorth Berwick Community Council were dismayed to hear that a resident in North Berwick received threatening letters during the lockdown period.ldquoIf anyone has concerns regarding whether or not someone  is flaunting the rules, concerns should be addressed to the non-emergency police line,  and the police will investigate and act as necessary.It is not known who sent both letters andthe incidents are linked.Reaction to both letters from the local community has been one of horror and disgust, calling it ldquounbelievable and ldquoheartbreaking.One inidual said they had to report someone for bullying her elderly mum after they told her that she could not go into her garden and feed the birds, something she enjoys doing.Iain Gray, MSP for East Lothian, said: ldquoI understand the anger there has been at times over the last few weeks when people think others have flouted official guidance, but this kind of behaviour is totally unacceptable.ldquoNobody should be trying to take matters into their own hands during the lockdown, especially as there is every chance they wonrsquot have the full picture on other peoplersquos circumstances.ldquoIf anyone has concerns about the actions of others during the lockdown they should report it to the appropriate authorities to be properly investigated.Police Scotland were asked to comment but had not responded by our deadline.However, the Courier is aware ldquonumerous calls have been made to police in Haddington about people potentially breaching restrictions during the coronavirus outbreak.Government guidelines have restricted the movement of people, with it recommended that members of the public only leave their home when necessary.Police Constable Charlie Duncan, Haddington and Lammermuir ward officer, highlighted the ongoing situation in a report to the townrsquos community council.The group had been due to meet earlier this month but postponed the meeting due to restrictions on social gatherings.PC Duncan sent members an e-mail and said: ldquoGiven the recent regulations and guidelines in relation to the COVID- virus, there has been a vast reduction in anti-social behaviour reported.ldquoThere has however been numerous calls in relation to possible breaches of these regulations and guidelines.ldquoThese have been dealt with and suitable advice given in the first instance.

title: hmrc-furlough-portal-government-scheme-opens-applications---apply
story: Under the scheme by the UK Government- which opened on Monday morning-employers will be able to pay their employees  per cent of their usual wage, up to a maximum of pound, per month.What do I the following details for each employee:How do I make a claim To make a claim, you will need your Government Gateway user ID and password.This will have been given to you when you registered for PAYE title: dunbear-bit-ahead-celebrity-bbc-programme
story: The five-metre high DunBear sculpture, created by renowned Scottish artist, Andy Scott, the man behind the lsquoKelpiesrsquo, will don the virtual eye patch, which will be promoted via social media, as a means to encourage people to give to the cause.The programme, which takes place this eveningat pm, is raising funds for local projects across the UK during the coronavirus pandemic.Stars such as Sir Lenny Henry, Davina McCall and Gary Barlow will take part in the event on BBC, with DunBear doing his bit with a Pudsey-style eyepatch.Iniduals are also being encouraged to contribute to Dunbar charity, The Ridge.The good cause, recognised for its outstanding work with young people, has joined forces with Dunbarrsquos community council as it shts its focus to providing practical support for those of all ages adversely affected by Covid-.Jointly managed funds are already making a dference by providing food, clothes, toys and books.A hot meals service is underway and The Ridge will direct and support people to debt advice services, mental health services and counselling.Small grants are available to groups, charities or iniduals where such a grant will help people in crisis.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of Dunbar Community Council, praised The Ridgersquos work and said: ldquoTheir community work places them in the very best position to take a lead in helping iniduals and families during the Covid- crisis and beyond and any funds raised will be directed fully to those in most need of help.The sculpture celebrates one of Dunbarrsquos most famous sons, John Muir, born on Tuesday this week in , who is credited with playing a key role in the development of Americarsquos national parks.It forms part of the mixed-use Hallhill development, which has already delivered sports facilities,  acres of community woodland together with more than , homes, either built or under construction.To support The Ridge go to paypal.me The RidgeDunbar locale. xen_GB

title: sir-hew-dalrymple-appointed-new-deputy-lieutenant
story: Sir Hew Dalrymple, of Blackdykes Farm, near North Berwick, whose family own the Bass Rock and have been active in East Lothian le for more than  years, takes on the role.His late father, Sir Hew Hamilton-Dalrymple, who died in December  at the age of , was a former Lord Lieutenant of East Lothian.Lord Lieutenants are employed by the Queen and carry out a range of duties in their counties, aided by their deputies.Sir Hew is a successful businessman involved in a wide range of companies as a business consultant, mentor and marketing adviser.He has roles in a number of North Berwick groups and organisations, and also runs the family property and farming company, through which he was involved in the setting up of Leuchie House as a national respite centre as landlord and adviser.Sir Hew was also a founding trustee of the Scottish Seabird Centre and is president of North Berwick RNLI and North Berwick Yacht Club.Michael Williams, East Lothianrsquos Lord Lieutenant, said: ldquoI am very pleased to welcome Sir Hew as a Deputy Lieutenant for East Lothian, as he brings with him an invaluable knowledge of community and commercial le across our county.ldquoIt is also particularly appropriate as his late father also served as a Deputy Lieutenant before becoming East Lothianrsquos Lord Lieutenant for  years.

title: developer-help-cover-extension-west-barns-primary-school
story: West Barns Primary School currently has four classrooms and a temporary nursery housing a single classroom.However, that could all change with an extension being proposed by East Lothian Council.An East Lothian Council spokeswoman said: ldquoWe have submitted a planning application to expand the nursery space at West Barns Primary School and provide additional facilities for the school.ldquoThe proposals would see the existing nursery temporary unit replaced with a larger nursery, as well providing the school with a new library and an additional classroom for primary one.ldquoWe have secured developer contributions from CALA Homes for the classroom works at West Barns and funds will also be received from the Scottish Governmentrsquos  grant for the nursery expansion.ldquopound.m has been set aside in our five-year capital programme for the project.CALA Homes have planning permission for nearly  homes to the east of the primary school, off Edinburgh Road.Plans for the school extension are currently with the local authorityrsquos planning department.
